case: Sarah receives an email from her bank asking her to click a link and enter her password to verify her account.
explanation: This is PHISHING! Real banks never ask for passwords via email. Always check URLs and contact the bank directly.

case: Mike downloads a free game from a torrent site and it asks him to disable his antivirus first.
explanation: MALWARE ALERT! Legitimate software never asks you to disable security. Torrent sites are full of viruses.

case: Lisa shares her Netflix password with her best friend so they can watch together.
explanation: Account SHARING violates terms of service and is illegal. Each person needs their own account.

case: Tom finds a WiFi network named 'Free Airport WiFi' and connects without a password.
explanation: This could be a HACKER'S TRAP! Public WiFi without passwords is often fake. Use mobile data or VPN.

case: Jenny posts her exact address and daily routine on social media.
explanation: DANGEROUS oversharing! This helps stalkers and burglars plan crimes. Keep personal details private.

case: David clicks on a pop-up saying 'Your computer is infected - call this number now!'
explanation: TECH SUPPORT SCAM! Close pop-ups immediately. Never call numbers from suspicious alerts.

case: Emma receives a text from an unknown number offering her a free iPhone.
explanation: SMS SCAM! If it sounds too good to be true, it is. Delete and block the sender.

case: Alex uses the same password 'password123' for email, bank, and social media.
explanation: PASSWORD REUSE is dangerous! Use unique, strong passwords and a password manager.
